key_points: Most Americans support Twitter's permanent suspension of President Donald Trump after the Capitol siege, but most Republicans do not.
61% of Americans agreed with the ban due to risks of further violence incitement, whereas 39% opposed it.
Facebook also banned Trump at least until after President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration, with the possibility of an indefinite ban.
John Gerzema, CEO of The Harris Poll, stated American Business Community leadership is sought by citizens in the absence of political action.
Opinions on the ban are split along partisan lines: 36% of Republicans support the ban compared to 80% of Democrats and 59% of independents.
Concerns about censorship arise among Republicans, with 36% of Americans concerned, but 69% agree social media can remove dangerous users.
40% believe Trump should have been banned earlier, labeling the action 'too little, too late.'
37% felt embarrassed by Trump's ban from Twitter.
58% agree removing Trump was correct due to his dangerous actions, and 42% fear it sets a censorship precedent.
A Morning Consult poll found half of Americans believe social media should have banned Trump earlier, with partisan differences in opinion on the bans.
